awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Explaining Public Opposition to Government  Assistance Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
General Summary

A great deal of research in political science and psychology shows that racial prejudice is a substantial component of race-based policy opposition. Some work suggests that prejudice is most likely to play a role when racial appeals are subtle and covert. Other work contends that people use higher-level cognitive processes to inhibit prejudiced instincts and abide by egalitarian social norms when race is explicit. In other words, when people are encouraged to think more about racial policies, they should be able to recognize and restrain the racial biases that might otherwise influence their opinions. This study test the contention that higher-level cognitive processes reduce the role of prejudice against the research hypothesis that higher-level cognitive processes may in some instances reinforce and even exacerbate the role of prejudice because of conscious motivations to reject egalitarian norms. 

Technical Summary

Building on work in social neuroscience, this project uses functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) to directly observe the neural mechanisms by which prejudice influences policy attitudes. A 2 (race: White vs. Black) x 2 (conscious awareness: implicit/non-conscious racial primes vs. explicit/conscious primes) within-subjects experiment is used to examine the impact of racial biases on support for various government assistance programs when the race of the programs' recipients is consciously versus subconsciously known. The PI hypothesizes that racial biases will be stronger when race is implicit, and that this relationship is mediated by increased activity in the amygdala and right insula and decreased activity in the prefrontal cortex and anterior cingulate cortex. However, the PI expects that racial biases will exist when race is explicit. If the key to diminishing the role of prejudice is to get people to think more about race, these biases will be due to a lack of controlled processing even when race is explicitly indicated by lower levels of activation in the prefrontal cortex and anterior cingulate cortex and increased activity in the amygdala and right insula. However, if controlled processes sometimes lead to reinforcement of prejudice, there will be no relationship between racial biases in policy support and activation in the prefrontal cortex or anterior cingulate cortex.

por.por_cntn:
The Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant (DDRIG) allowed Frank Gonzalez to collect data for a chapter in his dissertation, and thus complete his doctoral dissertation. The broader focus of the dissertation is on investigating the psychological processes underlying people’s attitudes toward government assistance. Specifically, Gonzalez utilized an array of survey and laboratory experiments to examine when people’s support for government assistance policies was driven by group-based prejudice versus ideological values. The chapter funded by the DDRIG allowed Gonzalez to collect functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) data in order to study the neural mechanisms of when ideological values rather than prejudice drive people’s evaluations of government assistance. As such, the data collected via the DDRIG funding contributed to the development of a theoretical framework for how prejudice affects attitudes toward government assistance, and when ideological values can override the role of prejudice.

The DDRIG funding was used to run 28 adults through the fMRI study, which involved various brain scans during the completion of a computer task related to government assistance. The findings of the study revealed that areas of the brain associated with controlled, effortful thought were particularly active when participants evaluated government assistance to Black applicants, and this pattern of results was mainly evident when the race of the applicant was consciously known (versus subliminally primed). Further, these brain activation patterns were most pronounced among individuals who were the most ideologically extreme in terms of their beliefs about how groups in society should be organized.

The results of this experiment therefore contribute to the framework developed throughout the dissertation, which suggests “controlled processing” – or effortful, deliberative thought – is triggered when people think about race and this leads people to defer to their ideological principles when evaluating government assistance programs. This runs counter to much prior literature and thinking, which has suggested that getting people to “think about race” will universally lead to them having more liberal, egalitarian views. Instead, this framework – corroborated by the results of the MRI study – suggests effortful thought centered on race is associated with ideological extremity in either direction. These findings significantly advance existing literature on the topic because they allow for direct observation of the neural processes that have been assumed or labeled as “unobservable” in prior research. By using fMRI to observe neural functioning, these longstanding assumptions were challenged.

The findings of this experiment, and its theoretical contributions more broadly, have substantial implications for how we think about public policies that involve government assistance to disadvantaged groups. Public opinion toward government assistance policies carries significant weight in determining how much funding such policies receive or whether they are implemented at all. If group-based prejudice is seen as an adverse influence on public opinion toward government assistance policies, scholars and practitioners may benefit from understanding the mechanisms of when it is most likely to drive opinions, when it can be “overridden,” and what the implications of “overriding” prejudice are.
